body:
- handling rejected promises, does the public specification provide any guidelines on this... ideally this module should match the error signatures used by the public version.  Perhaps a complimentary module that can interrogate the error to give a more useful sub-type for the given error message?
- Redirect headers, perhaps a `history` on the response, containing any response objects through a history chain the first entry being the first response then the redirect chain, until the final result.
  - each entry in history is a response object
  - entries in history do not have a `history` property, only the final response
  - the final response is not included in `history`
  - history will be `undefined` unless there are values (will never be a 0 array)
    - this will allow a simpler `if (res.history)` kind of check instead of `if (res.history && res.history.length)` ... not really required, but an idea

Note: neither of the above suggestions would require a 2.0 bump as they would be additive... for the history, once implemented, would put forward an issue to chromium/safari/ie/firefox to add the feature and to whatwg to extend the standard.

@tracker1 Thx for the suggestions.

Just to clarity, item 2 isn't possible with Fetch spec because of security issue, so I don't expect spec to change. see https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#atomic-http-redirect-handling

For item 1 there isn't a standard, if we are to tackle it, we will have to come up with ours. see https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/25

Good news is there are many alternatives to workaround these Fetch limits, so I am not jumping to solve them now.

issue.title: Implement request redirect modes

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.body:
Hi !

I implemented one missing piece of the spec that I need to see working about redirects.

Related spec part: https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/\#concept-request-redirect-mode

body:
We are now collecting feedbacks on what sort of data a rejected `Error` should contain (besides current `err.message`), suggestion much appreciated.

For example, we can give it:
- `err.status` for easier debugging and error handling.
- `err.headers` for peeking into redirection headers when you are not following redirects.

As we don't see such needs ourselves (we don't write special case for different errors, so `err.message` is simply a hint for debugging), wonder what else ppl are interested in.

Note: `Error` here refer to Network error, Redirection error or Parser error etc., remote server errors such 4xx, 5xx are resolved per Fetch spec.

Also: no promise on release timeline, too busy for proper 2.x :)

issue.title: POST redirection

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.body:
Hi there!

Im doing a fetch to an URL with POST (a login), which will redirect to another url if the login is successfull.

When this happends, fetch will try to follow the new url with the POST method too.
Shouldnt it follow the URL with a GET?

like in here: https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/blob/master/index.js#L127
Adding options.method='GET' just before that line.

Thanks!

body: Are there plans to add http proxy support?

@weijarz you will need to create a custom http.Agent or https.Agent with proxy support, and pass it as options `agent`.

ref:
https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch#options
https://github.com/TooTallNate/node-http-proxy-agent

@bitinn Regarding the error reporting - is there any possibility we'd pass the server's rejection along with the error so that it can be handled? Right now we're forcing the server to put all relevant information in `message` because we're ignoring everything else. I'd like to be able to catch the server's response and do something with it myself. 

I'd be happy to help with a PR if this is something we can.

@aarongreenwald may I double-check your use-case? if your server is returning something, you should be able catch it (body and headers). it's only when you encounter network error, you will see a rejected promise. even 4xx and 5xx are fulfilled promise (per spec).

issue.title: Support the `redirect: 'error' | 'manual' | 'follow'` option

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.body: I need to get the original request, not any redirect (nor the error I get with `follow: 0`), so the standard option would be useful.

issue.title: Credentials support?

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.body:
On client-side we can deal with cookies specifying `credentials` option.
https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-request-credentials-mode
But, have any idea about cookies on server-side (node-fetch)?

body: @aarongreenwald looking at `nock` document, I assume you are returning a JSON? it's in the `res.body` stream, but you can call `return res.json()` to get your JSON object on the next `then` call. See if examples in readme help you.
